channel.title: Simple Server Port Checker
channel.description:
Well I was going to write a set of AIO server development tools. I started writing this and finished it and I had no idea what else to put in the tool set, so I thought I might as well just make this a single release for now. I made this in VB.net 2008. You put in the host(IP) name, such as "server.no-ip.org" and the port to check. The defaults are set as 127.0.0.1 on port 43594. This isn't much of a release, but it's a small efficient tool you can use to quickly check if your port, or the port of another server is open. Please comment, rage and flame me all you like, and constructive criticism is always welcome. If anyone has any idea for tools to go into my AIO Tool Kit, just leave a message below.
Download: [url=http://uppit.com/0q3j3u2bez2j/PortChecker.rar]Click Me[/url]
[img]http://desmond.imageshack.us/Himg4/scaled.php?server=4&filename=portcheck1.png&res=landing[/img]

item.dc:creator: @Onix Onix
item.description:
@Onix wrote:

[quote=“dds specz reborn, post:17, topic:444381”]Very nice work i was actually looking for something like this, and you done it by your self i wish i could =p[/quote]It is actually really simple once you see the code. Thus the name has ‘Simple’ in it.

item.title: Simple Server Port Checker
item.dc:creator: @Onix Onix
item.description:
@Onix wrote:

[quote=“Bellend, post:15, topic:444381”]Goto google, search Port checker vb2010 theres 6 the exact same[/quote]I actually wrote all of this myself thanks. The thing is with a simple thing like this, all of them will look similar, since it’s the easiest way to display the information. If you made something like this, I can assure you the interface would look similar, would it not? Using anything else for displaying the open ports would just be pointless. But thanks for the criticism, next time I’ll have to work on my layout and ‘uniqueness’.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Onix wrote:

[quote=“JavaTC, post:11, topic:444381”]inb4 new member who hosts a leeched server doesn’t know what a port is.

In all seriousness, great tool, despite it’s simplicity.[/quote]I think simplicity is good. It allows even the most simple minded people to know how to use this.
